I added NetBSD to the list, and I checked with adg before submitting
that change.

Please see https://codereview.appspot.com/6660047.

We have binary distributions for FreeBSD (only amd64), I can't see why
we couldn't
do the same for NetBSD.

Things still seem a bit shaky with both NetBSD and OpenBSD. For Go 1.1,
Andrew argues that we should not to expand the set of officially supported
operating systems. Counter-arguments welcome.

On Sat, Mar 16, 2013 at 3:22 AM, Russ Cox <rsc@golang.org> wrote:
> Things still seem a bit shaky with both NetBSD and OpenBSD. For Go 1.1,
> Andrew argues that we should not to expand the set of officially supported
> operating systems. Counter-arguments welcome.
I tend to agree that we should exclude OpenBSD in official supported OSes
for Go 1.1 as its cgo support is still a hack.

But things are different for NetBSD, and I believe it's fully supported.
(except NetBSD/ARM, the qemu builder always fail the same test without a
reason, that test could indeed pass when running on actual hardware)

If we don't expand supported OS list with Go 1.1, these systems will have to
wait for another year, I don't think it's necessary.
(If we don't claim support for it, people won't use it, and in turn we still
won't know if it's ready for release support in Go 1.2)

[+bsiegert]

My gut feeling was based on a total unfamiliarity with Go on NetBSD. If
actual NetBSD users have been using Go for a while and haven't noticed any
significant problems, and Russ feels okay about cgo support on NetBSD (or
at least as confident as he does about cgo on FreeBSD), then I'm happy to
leave NetBSD support in.

I will, however, need access the NetBSD builders in order to build the
official tarballs. They're run by you (minux) and Benny, right?

On 16 March 2013 06:48, minux <minux.ma@gmail.com> wrote:

> If we don't expand supported OS list with Go 1.1, these systems will have
> to
> wait for another year, I don't think it's necessary.
>

The only thing they need to wait a year for is an official pre-built tar.gz
and installation instructions. These things can be provided by the
community, so it's not too bad if NetBSD misses 1.1. But like I said above,
that needn't be the case if NetBSD users feel good enough about Go support.

Andrew

I don't use Go on NetBSD a lot, but I use the mercurial distribution
to build Go for both NetBSD and Plan 9 and the NetBSD build occurs
more frequently than the Plan 9 one.

As a result, in my opinion Go on NetBSD/386 is at least as robust as
on Plan 9, suggesting that support for NetBSD ought to be on a par for
these platforms.  Of course, this is a subjective view.

Lucio.

> least as confident as he does about cgo on FreeBSD), then I'm happy to leave

So I used Go on NetBSD for a while and have not noticed any
significant problems. A few people have tested the work-in-progress Go
package I made for pkgsrc and saw no show-stoppers either.

> I will, however, need access the NetBSD builders in order to build the
> official tarballs. They're run by you (minux) and Benny, right?

Yes. I can add an account for you, no problem.

As for NetBSD/arm, I will try to get an ARM board ASAP (maybe a Pi now
that they are supported correctly?) and try to run a builder on real
hardware. Maybe I can leave it running on my desk, like you do for the
Darwin one.

--Benny.

On Saturday, March 16, 2013, Benny Siegert wrote:
>
> As for NetBSD/arm, I will try to get an ARM board ASAP (maybe a Pi now
> that they are supported correctly?) and try to run a builder on real

note: you need to get at least ARMv6, and preferably ARMv7 system.
running all.bash on RPi will take at least 3 hours (i've posted complete
build
log with timing on this list).

before that, could we raise runtime test timeout?
the qemu builder could get to the second runtime test now, but
all attempts failed with test timeout.

> note: you need to get at least ARMv6, and preferably ARMv7 system.

Any recommendation for a faster ARM board that works with NetBSD?

--Benny.

On Wednesday, March 20, 2013, Benny Siegert wrote:

> On Tue, Mar 19, 2013 at 9:11 PM, minux <minux.ma@gmail.com <javascript:;>>
> wrote:
> > note: you need to get at least ARMv6, and preferably ARMv7 system.
> > running all.bash on RPi will take at least 3 hours (i've posted complete
> > build
> > log with timing on this list).
> Any recommendation for a faster ARM board that works with NetBSD?
>
as i haven't tried any other boards, i can't give a recommendation.
netbsd supports pandaboard/beagleboard, so you can give them a try.
(note: there could be some memory problems with pandaboard,
as my linux/arm builder exhibited memory failures after running
continuously for several months; it might be a linux kernel issue,
but i still suggest avoid using pandaboard as builder)

perhaps you can ask on the port-arm mailing list as a lot of boards are
supported (look at /usr/src/sys/arch/evbarm/conf for a partial list), just
skip any ARM9 (ARMv5) ones.
